Award.AwardTitle: ICES: Small: Institutions for Cooperation in Large Economies of Strangers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Developed economies are largely based on impersonal exchange; trade does not require high levels of information about others' past behavior. Consequently, lack of trust, social distance, the possibility to break promises and other trade frictions all hinder economic activity. This project employs theoretical and experimental methodologies to study individual and group behavior in economies populated by individuals who do not know each other and may not trust each other. These strangers interact in pairs with randomly changing opponents whose identities and past behaviors are unknown. In each trade encounter, individuals can either cooperate or behave opportunistically. The sequence of encounters is indefinite, so many outcomes are possible. Theoretically, self-regarding individuals can overcome opportunistic temptations, and attain the best outcome, by adopting community-based punishment schemes. The research will pursue a systematic study of small and large laboratory economies based on these indefinitely repeated matching games. It will advance knowledge in the social and economic sciences by identifying behavioral elements and endogenously-arising institutions that are associated to the emergence, sustainability, and breakdown of cooperation among individuals who may neither know nor trust each other. New insights about cooperation will have applications to disciplines in which the study of social decision problems is an active area of research, such as political science, accounting, and sociology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interactions in modern societies primarily take place among strangers, which is to say among individuals who may not know each other and may not trust each other. Strangers cannot rely on the evolutionary and motivational forces of reciprocity and reputation to discourage opportunism and to promote cooperativeness. This poses a significant problem, as it weakens modern societies' cohesion, which may ultimately undermine the long-run prosperity of nations.

The research conducted under this NSF grant has pursued a systematic study of small and large economies, modeled as groups individuals who interact over a long horizon, as strangers. It has advanced knowledge in the social and economic sciences by identifying behavioral elements and institutions that are associated with the emergence, sustainability, and breakdown of cooperation in society. The research has studied the role of a variety of cooperation-enhancing institutions, and it has especially focused on monetary systems, institutions that are ubiquitous but whose behavioral properties are little understood.

To attain these goals the project has developed a unique theoretical and experimental methodology. This methodology, and the insights that have emerged frm the empirical segment of the project, are applicable to disciplines in which the study of social decision problems is an active area of research, e.g., accounting, anthropology, economics, political science, and sociology.


Through the activity conducted, the project has established an effective way to design laboratory economies of strangers, large and small. This goal has been accomplished by developing a theoretical framework to study--through the lens of well-recognized economic theory--strategic decision-making in groups of repeatedly interacting individuals. The framework is flexible, analytically tractable, and it is well-suited for empirical investigation. Theoretical hypotheses have been tested by developing an easily adaptable, computer-based experimental design, which has been successfully employed to collect behavioral data through a series of controlled laboratory experiments. The experiments have involved undergraduate participants arrayed in small and large groups, and interacting under a variety of institutional and informational settings.


Strong empirical evidence has emerged that maximum economic welfare is seldom attained when individuals interact as strangers, even if such a desirable outcome is within easy theoretical reach according to current economic thinking. Norms of cooperation seldom emerge in practice, especially as groups get larger, even when interaction is indefinitely repeated and others' past conduct can be publicly monitored to a certain extent. The research has empirically demonstrated that prototypical monetary systems tend to spontaneously emerge in such cases, to overcome cooperative challenges. That type of institutional development promotes and preserves cooperation as groups get larger, and fosters cohesion and long-run prosperity of the group. An evolutionary model has been developed to explain this evidence. Variants of the basic theoretical framework have been experimentally tested and results have been found to be robust to changes in design, parameters, timing of actions and, to a certain extent, institutional settings.


Results from the research conducted under this grant have been disseminated worldwide to communities of interest through academic publications, Internet dissemination, conference presentations, University workshops, and interviews with the popular press. The project has also generated valuable opportunities for training and professional development of several graduate students.
